text: Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup (August 24, 1905 – March 28, 1974) was a delta blues singer and guitarist. He wrote songs that Elvis Presley later sang. == Life and career == === Early life === Crudup was born in Forest, Mississippi, and worked as a migrant worker until he and his family went back to Mississippi in 1926. === Early career === Crudup sang gospel music and blues music. He played in a band called the Harmonizing Four in 1939. A record producer called Lester Melrose got him work with the Bluebird label. === Later career === Crudup stopped recording in the 1950s. His last Chicago recording was in 1951. He also recorded in 1952–54 for a radio station called WGST in Atlanta.Groom, Bob, Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup, Complete Recorded Works Vol.3 (11 March 1949 to 15 January 1952) DOCD-5203, Document Records, 1993. In the 1960s he started recording again with Fire Records and Delmark Records. === Later life === In the mid 60s, Crudup went back to working as a farmer in Virginia, where he lived with his family: his three sons and several of his own siblings. == Death == He died because of heart disease and diabetes. He died in the Nassawadox hospital in Northampton County, Virginia, also on the Eastern Shore in 1974. == References == ==Other websites== * Biography of Arthur Crudup * Biography of Arthur Crudup Category:1905 births Category:1974 deaths Category:Blues guitarists Category:Singers from Mississippi Category:American guitarists Category:Musicians from Mississippi
